docs.lead_paragraph: BMC Software, a maker of programs that manage corporate computer networks, agreed yesterday to buy closely held OpenNetwork for $18 million in cash. BMC, based in Houston, said the acquisition would help expand its ability to let customers manage access to Web-based applications. OpenNetwork, based in Clearwater, Fla., has customers in the financial services, insurance, telecommunications and health care industries, BMC said. BMC shares rose 1 cent, to $15.41.

But now, from airlines to manufacturers of advanced plastics, many businesses are overcoming their fears of losing customers and are starting to pass on cost increases.

headline.main: Price Increases By Companies Start to Stick

docs.lead_paragraph: Altiris, which makes software used to manage computer systems, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire closely held Pedestal Software for $65 million in cash to add network security products. Altiris said the acquisition would add to earnings starting in the third quarter, and was expected to contribute $17 million to $18 million in revenue in 2005. Gregory S. Butterfield, the Altiris chief executive, said Pedestal's customers in the insurance, health care and financial services industries offered new sales opportunities and its products would help Altiris compete with rivals like Symantec, NetIQ and BindView Development. Mr. Butterfield said he expected to raise prices on Pedestal products by as much as 20 percent, to about $800 for server computers that run corporate networks and to about $30 for personal computers. Pedestal, which is based in Newton, Mass., employs about 50 people. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the month. Altiris, based in Lindon, Utah, reported net income of $16.7 million on revenue of $166.6 million in 2004.

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's main building-service workers union is taking an unusual step to ensure that hundreds of janitors, doormen and security guards at apartment buildings planned for two Brooklyn neighborhoods are paid union-scale wages. The union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, persuaded allies in the City Council to introduce legislation yesterday that would require residential developers planning projects in Williamsburg and Greenpoint to pay the prevailing union wage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing their worst financial outlook in years, executives at General Motors said yesterday that they wanted union workers to accept the same health benefit cuts already taken by white-collar workers. ''We need a competitive plan for all of our employees,'' said Gary Cowger, G.M.'s head of North American operations, in a speech at the New York International Auto Show. ''An across-the-board competitive health care plan for salaried and hourly employees could save us billions of dollars a year.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The long-term financial condition of the Social Security system deteriorated slightly over the last year, the government reported on Wednesday, and President Bush's supporters immediately said this strengthened the case for enacting a fundamental change in the program this year. In their annual report to Congress, the trustees of the Social Security and Medicare programs said Social Security reserves would be depleted in 2041, one year earlier than was projected last year. But the trustees emphasized, as they did last year, that Medicare's financial outlook was ''much worse than Social Security's'' and predicted that the monthly Medicare premiums paid by almost all Americans 65 and older would rise by 12 percent next year after a 17 percent increase this year.

headline.main: Medicare Outlook Called Direr Than Social Security's

docs.abstract: Annual report to Congress by trustees of Social Security and Medicare says Social Security reserves will be depleted in 2041, one year earlier than was projected last year, but warns that Medicare's financial outlook is worse; predicts monthly Medicare premiums will rise by 12 percent next year after 17 percent increase this year and that its hospital trust fund will be depleted in 2020; Pres Bush's top legislative priority this year is to transform Social Security, although he has conceded that plan for private accounts would not improve financial condition; graphs show projected involvencies and long-term costs of both programs (M)
docs.snippet: A report predicted that the monthly Medicare premiums paid by almost all Americans 65 and older would rise by another 12 percent next year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fifteen people, including four doctors, a dentist and a psychologist, have been charged in a medical insurance fraud, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday. Mr. Morgenthau said a mother and son team had engineered the scheme, using their control of a billing company and clinics to charge for services and tests that were never provided. The victims were insurance companies and New York City Transit, which insures its employees. Mr. Morgenthau did not specify the amount of the fraud, but said it added up to millions of dollars over a 10-year period. The accused pleaded not guilty to charges that included insurance fraud and grand larceny at State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a push to recruit older workers, Home Depot, the hardware chain, now offers ''snowbird specials'' -- winter work in Florida and summers in Maine. Borders bookstores lure retired teachers to sales jobs with discounts and the promise of reading and discussion groups. Pitney Bowes, the business services company, pays tuition for courses in computer programming as well as spare-time skills like golf and flower arranging.

headline.main: More Help Wanted: Older Workers Please Apply

docs.lead_paragraph: In the wild, wild west-of-the-Hudson city of Hoboken, N.J., the mayor is technically an outlaw, and he has called members of the City Council lawbreakers. In an emotional budget showdown with the Council, he sent home all but the most essential city workers yesterday, shutting down most of the city's government. The Council refused Mayor David Roberts's request to pass an emergency budget appropriation on Monday night to keep basic services running while they settle their differences. So Mr. Roberts ordered hundreds of Hoboken's employees to leave work yesterday afternoon, after he said through a spokesman that state officials had told him he would be committing a crime if he spent any money.

docs.lead_paragraph: As old-line American companies -- the last bastions of fully paid employee benefits -- struggle in global markets, fewer and fewer of them are able to shoulder 100 percent of workers' health insurance premiums. ''Employers simply can't afford the benefits they have promised,'' said Helen Darling, president of the National Business Group on Health, an organization of large employers in Washington. ''The auto companies are in the most trouble because they have some of the highest health costs and some of the toughest competition.''

headline.main: Fewer Employers Totally Cover Health Premiums

docs.abstract: Fewer and fewer companies are able to shoulder 100 percent of workers' health insurance premiums; scattering of comapnies in industries with strong unions like telecommunications, steel and autos, as well as few state governments still pay entire premium, but most employees are paying more each year as health costs soar; percentage of large and medium-size employers paying 100 percent of workers' individual premium plummeted to 17 percent in 2004 from 29 percent in 2000; most workers who are required to share premium costs are paying more each year; average share of premium paid by employees in large and medium-size companies is expected to reach $2,800 for family coverage and $800 for individuals this year, increase of 27 percents in family premium for $2,200 in 2003, and 23 percent rise from $650 in individual rate; graph (M)
